name: ARPANET
description:
- Advanced Research Projects Agency Network
- the first wide-area packet-switched network with distributed control and one of the first computer networks to implement the TCP/IP protocol suite. Both technologies became the technical foundation of the Internet.
- Initiated in 1966, first computers connected in 1969

name: Netscape Navigator
description:
- Developed by people who had developed Mosaic browser for NCSA in 1993. They had started company called Mosaic Communications Corporation in April 1994, and in october of the same year they released Mosaic Netscape 0.9 which was soon renamed to Netscape Navigator. The company was also renamed to Netscape.
- Internally referred to as Mozilla, meaning the Mosaic killer

name: JavaScript
description: - developed by Brendan Eich at Netscape

name: Java
description: - Java language project was initiated in 1991

name: Internet Explorer
description: - Released with Windows 95

name: RFC 1 “Host Software”
description: - Steve Crocker

name: GCC
description: GNU Compiler Collection

name: First rocks
description: Earth's surface had apparently been molten until then.

name: Earth Formed
description: The oldest meteorite fragments found.

name: The oldest undisputed evidence of life on Earth
description: Interpreted as fossilized bacteria, dates to 3 Ga. Other finds in rocks dated to about 3.5 Ga have been interpreted as bacteria, with geochemical evidence also seeming to show the presence of life 3.8 Ga. However, these analyses were closely scrutinized, and non-biological processes were found which could produce all of the "signatures of life" that had been reported.

name: Oldest evidence for microbial life
description: In the form of organic matter-rich paleosols, ephemeral ponds and alluvial sequences, some bearing microfossils

name: The first disputed evidence of life on Earth
description: Biologically fractionated graphite inside a single zircon grain in the Jack Hills range of Australia.

name: Homo sapiens
description:
Anatomically modern human.

The earliest fossil evidence of early modern humans appears in Africa around 300,000 years ago, with the earliest genetic splits among modern people, according to some evidence, dating to around the same time.

name: Chimpanzee–human last common ancestor
description: Seems to be quite unclear still. Studies in the early 2020s suggest a more recent CHLCA, such as between 9.3 and 6.5 million years ago in 2021, and studies giving even more recent dates are cited in a 2022 article.

name: Writing
description:
Four independent inventions of writing are most commonly recognized:
- Mesopotamia (c. 3400–3100 BC)
- Egypt (c. 3250 BC)
- China (before c. 1250 BC)
- Mesoamerica (before c. 1 AD)

name: Sickle
description: Tahunian culture, near Bethlehem.

name: Sargon of Akkad
description: A face mask (probably) depicting Sargon made sometime during the Akkadian period. Most likely representing either Sargon of Akkad or his grandson Naram-Sin.

name: Priest-King statue of Indus valley
description: The most famous statue of the Indus valley civilization.

name: Statue of a copulating couple from Babylonia
Harp player statue from Greek islands
description: Cyclades

name: Deer with silver decoration from Anatolia
description: Alaca, Anatolia

name: Mask of “Agamemnon”
description: Discovered at the Bronze Age site of Mycenae in southern Greece.

name: Ziggurat of Dur Kurigalzu
description: Founded by Kassite king of Babylon, Kurigalzu I

name: Ziggurat of Dur Untash
description: Choqa Zanbil, Persia

name: Mask of Tutankhamun
description: His grave was perhaps safe from robbers because he died fairly young (19) and was thus largely forgotten.

name: Merneptah stele
description: The earliest mention of Israel in any writing.

name: Olmec colossal heads
description: Olmec were an early known major Mesoamerican civilization, flourishing in the modern-day Mexican states of Veracruz and Tabasco from roughly 1200 to 400 BCE during Mesoamerica's formative period

name: CSS
description: Cascading Style Sheet

name: Crocodilia
description: The earliest stage of crocodilian evolution was the protosuchians in the late Triassic and early Jurassic.

name: Caniform and Feliform split
description: Around 50 million years ago, or earlier, in the Paleocene, the Carnivora split into two main divisions: caniform (dog-like) and feliform (cat-like).

name: Bird
description: Key features of Archaeopteryx that link it to birds include feathers and the ability to potentially glide or fly. However, it also had characteristics typical of theropod dinosaurs, such as teeth, a long bony tail, and claws on its wings. This mixture of traits made Archaeopteryx a crucial fossil in understanding the evolution of birds from theropod dinosaurs.

name: Domestication of Goat, Sheep, Pig, Cow
description: 11000 - 10000 years ago.

name: Domestication of Wheat and Barley
description: 13000 - 11000 years ago.

name: Domestication of Flax
description: 13000 - 11000 years ago.

name: Domestication of Chicken
description: Apparently for cockfighting rather than for food.

name: Last Glacial Period ended
description:
Started 115,000 years ago.

The last Glacial Maximum occurred 20,000 years ago.

name: Agricultural revolution
description: The prehistoric transition from hunting and gathering to settled agriculture (also known as the Neolithic Revolution).

name: Hand axe
description: A prehistoric stone tool with two faces.

name: Homo erectus
description: Walking upright. Spread from Africa to Eurasia.

name: Use of fire on daily basis
Neanderthals
description: Homo Neanderthalensis

name: Fictive language
description: Homo Sapiens spread to Arabian Peninsula and quickly to rest of the Eurasia.

name: Copper
description: Serbia

name: Stirrup
description: First few centuries AD.

name: Multicellular organism
description: The Francevillian biota (Also referred to as Gabon macrofossils, Gabonionta or Francevillian group fossils) are a collection of 2.1-billion-year-old Palaeoproterozoic macroscopic structures, controversially suggested to be fossils. The structures have been postulated by some authors to be evidence of the earliest form of multicellular life, and of eukaryotes

name: Fungus
description:
The oldest fossilizied mycelium to be identified from its molecular composition is between 715 and 810 million years old.

The earliest fossils possessing features typical of fungi date to the Paleoproterozoic era, some 2,400 million years ago (Ma); these multicellular benthic organisms had filamentous structures capable of anastomosis.[121] Other studies (2009) estimate the arrival of fungal organisms at about 760–1060 Ma on the basis of comparisons of the rate of evolution in closely related groups.

name: The last snowball earth
description:
The most academically mentioned period of such a global ice age is believed to have occurred some time before 650 mya during the Cryogenian period, which included at least two large glacial periods, the Sturtian and Marinoan glaciations.

The first Snowball Earth event is believed to have occurred during the Sturtian glaciation, around 720 to 700 million years ago.

Some propose there was a snowball earth already around 2300 B years ago when the atmosphere started to get oxygen-rich.

name: Milky Way
description:
The thin disk of our galaxy began to form when the universe was about 5 billion years old or 9 ± 2 Gya.

According to recent studies, the Milky Way as well as the Andromeda Galaxy lie in what in the galaxy color–magnitude diagram is known as the "green valley", a region populated by galaxies in transition from the "blue cloud" (galaxies actively forming new stars) to the "red sequence" (galaxies that lack star formation).

name: Andromeda
description: The Andromeda Galaxy (M31) is estimated to be around 10 billion years old, though some of its oldest stars and globular clusters may be as old as 13.5 billion years, similar to the Milky Way. Andromeda formed through multiple galaxy mergers over billions of years, which shaped it into the massive spiral galaxy we see today.

name: Jarmo
description: Abandoned 4950 BC

name: Woolly mammoth
description: The youngest fossils of the mainland population are from the Kyttyk Peninsula of Siberia and date to 9,650 years ago

name: Sabre-tooth tiger
description: Smilodon. Although commonly known as the saber-toothed tiger, it was not closely related to the tiger or other modern cats.

name: Çatalhöyük
description: Abandoned 5700 BC

name: Babylon
description: Abandoned 1000 AD

name: Sumer
description:
Most historians have suggested that Sumer was first permanently settled between c. 5500 and c. 3300 BC.

Abandoned 1800 BC

name: Nineveh
description: Abandoned 612 BC.

name: Assur
description: Archaeology reveals the site of the city was occupied by the middle of the 3rd millennium BC.

name: Uruk
description: Abandoned 700 AD

name: Ur
description: Abandoned 500 BC

name: Memphis
description: During the Early Dynastic Period (3150 BC - 2686 BC) and Old Kingdom, Memphis became the capital of Ancient Egypt for more than six consecutive dynasties.

name: Athens
description: Athens has been continuously inhabited for at least 5,000 years. By 1400 BC, the settlement had become an important centre of the Mycenaean civilization

name: Kish
description: Kish was occupied from the Ubaid period (5300-4300 BC). The Sumerian King List (2084-1648 BC) states that Kish was the first city to have kings following the deluge.

name: Sumerian King List
description:
Redacted to legitimize the claims to power of various city-states and kingdoms in southern Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennium BC.

Publication date (2084-1648 BC).

name: Indus Valley Civilization
description: Abandoned 1300 BC

name: Julius Caesar
description: Born 100 BC

name: Alexander the Great
description: Born 356 BC

name: Charlemagne
description: Born 748. Died 814. Holy Roman Emperor in 800.

name: Marcus Aurelius
description: Born 121.

name: Constantine the Great
description: Born 272. Died 337. Contested Roman Emperor since 306. Undisputed since 324.

name: Napoleon
description:
- 1769-1821
- 1804 Emperor of the French

name: Genghis Khan
description: Born 1162. Died 1227.

name: Christopher Colmubus
description: Born 1451. Died 1506.

name: Tutankhamun
description: Born 1341 BC. Died 1323 BC (aged 18-19).

name: First Intermediate Period
description: Ends 2055. (Overlaps with the next period)

name: Middle Kingdom
description: Ends 1690 BC

name: Roman period
description: Until 642 AD

name: Late Helladic
description: Until 1050 BC

name: Early Assyrian period
description: Until 2025 BC

name: Old Assyrian period
description: Until 1364 BC

name: Middle Assyrian Empire
description: Until 912 BC

name: Neo-Assyrian Empire
description: Until 609 BC

name: Akkadian Empire
description: Until 2154 BC

name: Troy II
description: Twice the size of the preceding city.

name: Troy VI
description:
Destroyed around 1300 BC. Indicative of an earthquake.

Troy VI–VII is believed to be the city referred to as Wilusa and Taruisa in Hittite records

name: Troy VIIa
description: Destroyed around 1180 BC.

name: Troy VIIb
description: Destroyed by fire around 950 BC.

name: Late Minoan
description: Until 1100 BC.

name: Mycenae
description: The dominant state in Greece during the Late Helladic period (1550-1050 BC).
